summary: A Palm Beach Post article from November 2007 reports on the impending resolution of the Jeffrey Epstein case. It states that Epstein is expected to plead guilty to a single felony count of solicitation of prostitution, avoiding a federal trial and a lengthy sentence, but potentially facing up to 18 months in prison and sex offender registration. The article details the conflict between local and federal authorities over the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the case, a Palm Beach billionaire accused of paying underage girls for sex. The article reports he is expected to plead guilty to felony solicitation of prostitution.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's lawyer in West Palm Beach who stated the case would end without a trial within two months.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Part of Epstein's 'dream team' of lawyers; commented in September on constitutional issues with the federal involvement in the case.

persons.name: Ken Starr
persons.context: Former Bill Clinton prosecutor and part of Epstein's legal defense team.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.context: His department conducted an 11-month investigation in 2005-06, surveilling Epstein's house. He requested federal help and feuded with the State Attorney over charges.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: The state prosecutor who feuded with Police Chief Reiter over charges for Epstein, accused by Reiter of going easy on him. Federal authorities agreed to let him proceed solo with the case.

connections.description: Goldberger is identified as Epstein's legal representative in West Palm Beach, speaking on his behalf about the case resolution.
Dershowitz is part of Epstein's 'dream team' of lawyers and publicly commented on constitutional issues in the case.
Starr is identified as a member of Epstein's legal defense team.
The Police Chief and State Attorney feuded over the charges for Epstein, with Reiter accusing Krischer of going easy on him.
Reiter's police department conducted an 11-month investigation into Epstein, surveilling his house and going through his garbage.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach Police spent 11 months surveilling Epstein's house and sifting through evidence, including sex toys, in his garbage.

events.title: Impending Guilty Plea Announcement
events.description: As reported in the article, Epstein is expected to plead guilty to one felony count of solicitation of prostitution, ending the case without a federal trial.

events.title: Dershowitz Comments on Case
events.description: Alan Dershowitz commented that there were constitutional issues with the federal government's involvement in the Epstein case.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was expected to plead guilty to a single felony count of solicitation of prostitution, avoiding a federal trial.
The proposed deal would result in up to 18 months in prison and potential sex offender registration for Epstein, far less than the lengthy federal sentence previously possible.
Palm Beach Police Chief Michael Reiter and State Attorney Barry Krischer had a public feud over the handling of the case, with Reiter accusing Krischer of going easy on Epstein.
Federal authorities (the FBI) initially investigated but, according to a source, agreed to let the state prosecutor proceed alone, which was seen as a victory for Epstein's defense team.
The Palm Beach Police conducted an 11-month investigation in 2005-06, which included surveillance of Epstein's house and examining the contents of his garbage.
